Introduction 

Babesiosis is an intraerythrocytic protozoal infection transmitted primarily by the Ixodes tick.  It is the second most common blood parasite worldwide after Plasmodium (malaria).  Babesia microti (United States, Asia) and Babesia divergens (Europe) are the leading species.  The major environmental reservoir is small vertebrates (eg, white-footed mice).  Asymptomatic infection can occur, but patients often develop clinically significant hemolytic anemia with flu-like symptoms (eg, fever, malaise, fatigue).  Those with asplenia or immunocompromise are at risk for severe, life-threatening complications.

Risk factors



  • Exposure to endemic areas (eg, Northeastern/Upper Midwestern United States).
  • Exposure to tick habitats (eg, high grass, edge of forest).
  • Nymphal Ixodes tick season (summer months).
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Risk for severe disease:
    • Asplenia/hyposplenism.
    • Immunocompromise (eg, AIDS, malignancy, immunotherapy).
    • Age >50.

Pathophysiology



The lifecycle of babesiosis involves vertebrate and invertebrate hosts.  Although many mammals (eg, chipmunks, squirrels) can harbor B microti, the most prominent reservoir is the white-footed mouse.  Ixodes larval ticks feed on mice in the late summer, molt into nymphs over the winter, and then transmit babesiosis to humans during bloodfeeding the following summer (May-September).  The reservoir and lifecycle of other Babesia species vary by geographic location and Ixodes vector.



Following human transmission during tick bloodfeeding, sporozoites enter the bloodstream, attach to the erythrocyte membrane, and invaginate, leading to the formation of a parasitophorous vacuole.  Within the erythrocyte, the sporozoite evolves into a ring-shaped trophozoite, which divides by binary fission into merozoites.  Merozoites then lyse the red blood cells and infect new erythrocytes.  Erythrocyte lysis increases proinflammatory cytokines, which can result in flu-like symptoms (eg, fever, malaise, headache, rigors).



Control of babesiosis is largely undertaken in the spleen, which traps infected erythrocytes as they pass through the red pulp.  Activated splenic macrophages then engulf and destroy the infected red blood cells.  As such, patients with splenectomy (as well as those with immunocompromise) are at greatest risk for life-threatening infection.

Pathology



The parasite can be visualized on a thin smear of peripheral blood with Giemsa or Wright stain.  Those with low amounts of parasitemia or patients with early infection may require multiple thin smears to identify an organism.  The most common finding is the presence of â‰¥1 intraerythrocytic ring forms.  Although this resembles Plasmodium (malaria), babesiosis is not associated with hemozoin (intraerythrocytic brown pigment) deposition.  More rarely, a tetrad formation (Maltese cross) (

) is visualized, which is pathognomonic for babesiosis.

Clinical presentation



The severity of infection is generally related to the level of parasitemia.  Patients who are immunocompetent typically have low levels of parasitemia (<4%) and may be asymptomatic or develop mild to moderate disease.  In contrast, those with immunocompromise, asplenia, or age >50 are more likely to have significant parasitemia (>4%) and to develop severe disease with complications.



Manifestations usually begin 1-4 weeks after transmission and may include the following:



  • Flu-like symptoms with intermittent/sustained fever, chills, sweats, and myalgia.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly (in some cases) due to trapping of infected erythrocytes.
  • Signs of hemolytic anemia (eg, low hematocrit, high lactate dehydrogenase, low haptoglobin, reticulocytosis).
  • Elevated indirect and direct bilirubin (scleral icterus is uncommon).
  • Thrombocytopenia.


Patients with severe disease typically also have nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; they are at greater risk for life-threatening complications, such as:



  • Renal insufficiency/failure.
  • Pulmonary failure (acute respiratory distress syndrome).
  • Congestive heart failure.
  • Severe anemia.
  • Shock.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation.


Rash is uncommon and suggests coinfection with Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease), which is also transmitted by Ixodes ticks.  Lymphadenopathy is not a feature of babesiosis.

Diagnosis



Babesiosis is largely a seasonal disease; most cases arise at the end of peak nymphal Ixodes tick season in August and September (in the United States).  Therefore, suspicion should be raised when a patient develops a flu-like illness with signs of hemolytic anemia on laboratory evaluation following exposure to an endemic area (especially during the late summer months).  Although far less common, the other major risk factor is recent blood transfusion (babesiosis can survive in blood in cold storage for up to 1 year).  Because Ixodes ticks can also transmit Lyme disease, human granulocytic anaplasmosis, and other infections, patients diagnosed with these infections generally require evaluation for babesiosis.



Diagnostic confirmation involves one of the following:



  • Blood smear microscopy:  Identifying the organism on thin blood smear using microscopy with Giemsa or Wright stain allows rapid confirmation of infection and quantification of parasitemia.  Multiple thin smears may be required when parasitemia is minimal.
  • PCR testing:  This test has high sensitivity and is useful when parasitemia is minimal or if microscopy is unavailable.


Serology can provide retrospective confirmation of babesiosis but has limited utility in the diagnosis of acute disease.  All patients with babesiosis require evaluation for other Ixodes-borne tick infections (eg, Lyme disease).

Differential diagnosis



  • Malaria:  Patients also develop a flu-like illness with hemolysis and intraerythrocytic ring-shaped forms.  However, malaria has a different geographic distribution (eg, Africa, tropical climates) and hemozoin depositions (intraerythrocytic brownish pigment) are seen on microscopy.  In addition, Maltese cross patterns are not seen.
  • Lyme disease:  Lyme disease is also transmitted by Ixodes ticks and may cause flu-like symptoms.  However, a migrating, annular rash is often present (in early localized disease), patients do not have signs of hemolysis, and no intraerythrocytic parasites are seen on microscopy.
  • Anaplasmosis:  Anaplasmosis can cause flu-like symptoms, thrombocytopenia, and nonhemolyotic anemia.  Blood smear can sometimes identify intracytoplasmic inclusions (morulae) in neutrophils, which confirm the diagnosis.  Hemolytic anemia and intraerythrocytic parasites are not seen.
  • Leptospirosis:  This widespread spirochetal infection is typically acquired when humans accidentally ingest the bacterium from contaminated food or water (urine of infected animals).  Although patients typically develop flu-like symptoms, conjunctival hyperemia (suffusion) is often seen, hemolysis is uncommon, and no intraerythrocytic parasites are present.
  • Noninfectious causes of hemolytic anemia:  No intraerythrocytic parasites are seen.

Management



  • Asymptomatic individuals:

    • No antimicrobial treatment is required unless there is persistent parasitemia for >1 month.
  • Mild to moderate disease (typically immunocompetent with parasitemia <4%):
    • Oral azithromycin plus atovaquone (first line).
    • Oral clindamycin plus quinone (alternative regimen).
  • Severe disease (typically parasitemia >4%):
    • Intravenous azithromycin plus oral atovaquone (first line).
    • Intravenous clindamycin plus oral quinine (alternative regimen).
    • Patients require hospitalization, supportive care, and (sometimes) red blood cell exchange transfusion.
  • Relapsed disease (usually severely immunocompromised patients):
    • Reduce immunosuppression if possible.
    • Repeat course of antimicrobial therapy (typically with the same agents previously used).

Complications



Complications are most common in patients who have severe disease in the setting of immunosuppression, asplenia/hyposplenia, or age >50.  Common complications include the following:



  • Severe hemolytic anemia requiring transfusion.
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Renal insufficiency/failure.
  • Congestive heart failure.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation.
  • Splenic rupture (rare).
  • Relapsed disease (usually within 1-2 months after treatment discontinuation).
  • Coinfection with other Ixodes tick pathogens (eg, Lyme disease).

Prognosis



Patients with asymptomatic infection are typically able to clear the parasite and usually experience no residual complications.  Immunocompetent individuals with mild to moderate disease generally have improvement in symptoms within 48 hours of antimicrobial treatment initiation and complete resolution within 1-2 weeks.  Patients with severe babesiosis are at greatest risk for life-threatening infection, morbidity, and relapsed disease.
